speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the rash, when did it first appear, and how long have you been experiencing numbness and tingling sensations on your palms?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started about a year ago, I think it was during the harvest season, I was working long hours in the fields and haven't really noticed anything out of the ordinary back then. But over the past few months, the itching has gotten worse, especially on my face, and the numbness on my palms started about 6 months ago."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the duration of the numbness and tingling sensations on your palms, have they been constant or have they come and gone over time?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been pretty consistent, to be honest. I wake up every morning with it, and it's been there for the past 6 months. Sometimes it's a bit more pronounced than others, but it's always there, like a constant hum in the background."

speaker: Doctor
text: So the rash started about 6 months ago, and it's been getting progressively worse. Can you describe the rash to me - is it red, scaly, itchy, or does it have a specific pattern or distribution on your body?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's more of a tingling sensation, to be honest, and it's not really itchy, but more like a crawling feeling. The rash on my face is pretty much limited to the area around my eyebrows, it's a bit thinner and lighter than the rest of my hair, and it's been spreading over time. It's not really red or scaly, but more of a patchy, hypopigmented area."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the rash - does it tend to spread from one area to another, and have you noticed any triggers that make it worse or better?

speaker: Patient
text: "It does seem to spread a bit, especially around my hairline, and I've noticed it's more pronounced when I'm exposed to certain... let's call them 'environmental factors'. I don't know, it's hard to describe, but when the sun's out and the air's dry, it seems to get a bit worse, and when it's humid or rainy, it's almost like it calms down a bit."

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me if the rash is more pronounced on one side of your body than the other, or if it's symmetrical?

(Also, I'll request a test to take a closer look at the rash)

speaker: Patient
text: "It's more symmetrical, to be honest, I mean, I've got a bit of thinning around my eyebrows on both sides, and the hypopigmented patches seem to be about the same size on both cheeks."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the rash in more detail - is it dry, moist, or does it have any unusual characteristics, such as blisters or crusting?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's pretty dry, to be honest, and it doesn't really blister or crust. It's more of a... I don't know, a desiccated feeling, like the skin is just really tight and itchy, but not in a way that's painful. It's almost like the skin is just really... brittle."

speaker: Doctor
text:
I'd like to examine the rash more closely. Can you please extend your arm so I can take a closer look at the rash on your palms?



Also, I'd like to ask, have you noticed any other symptoms such as pain, swelling, or fever in addition to the numbness and tingling sensations?

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've taken note of all your responses and examined your hands thoroughly. Based on your symptoms, I'm going to make a diagnosis.

Can you please stand up and let me take a closer look at your overall condition? I'd like to assess your posture, muscle tone, and any other potential abnormalities.

Also, I'd like to thank you for your cooperation and patience throughout this examination. Your responses have been invaluable in helping me narrow down the possible causes of your symptoms.

Now, I'm going to make my diagnosis.

DIAGNOSIS READY: Raynaud's Phenomenon with Secondary Sjögren's Syndrome.
